page.title: 03LOCAL CUSTOMS-WEST NOTTINGHA
page.content: At Saint Leodagarius Church,Church Street, there is a pax stone, or kissing stone.It is a piece of stone built into the door frame.It was a holy piece of stone. A Pope sent it.It was from a saint's tomb.The congregation were supposed to kiss it. Originally the people kissed each other as a sign of neighbourly love but when the congregation grew they kissed the pax stone instead. A surviving local custom is the Basford Wakes. After Goose Fair the local children go to a smaller fun-fair on Billy Bacon's land near Basford Crossing. The original site was the Shoulder of Mutton car park, now known as "Thingymajigs". Children bring back presents from the Wakes and these are called 'fairings'.
